siteMetadata.title: Apollo GraphQL Docs
siteMetadata.description: A guide to using Apollo Server

children.value: This reference describes the lifecycle events that your
Apollo Server fires two types of events that plugins can hook into:
Server lifecycle events are high-level events related to the lifecycle of Apollo Server itself (e.g.,
Request lifecycle events are associated with the lifecycle of a specific request.
You define responses to these events
With two exceptions, all plugin methods in Apollo Server 3 are
, which is called much more frequently than other plugin methods. The second exception is
would introduce unclear ordering semantics around method executions.
event fires when Apollo Server is preparing to start serving GraphQL requests. The server doesn't start until this asynchronous method completes. If it throws (i.e., if the
and your server does not serve GraphQL operations. This helps you make sure all of your server's dependencies are available before attempting to begin serving requests.

handler, because the two handlers usually interact with the same data. Currently,
handlers do not take arguments (this might change in the future).

handler is called, Apollo Server is in a state where it will no longer start to execute new GraphQL operations, so it's a good place to flush observability data. If you are looking for a hook that runs while operations can still execute, try

If your plugin doesn't need to respond to any request lifecycle events,
event fires whenever Apollo Server initially loads the schema or updates the schema. A

If you're using TypeScript to create your plugin, implement the
module to define functions for request lifecycle events.
When Apollo Server processes a request, these events fire in the order listed (with the exception of
, which might fire in one of a few places depending on when errors occur).
Note that not every event fires for every request (for example,
doesn't fire for an operation that Apollo Server has cached and doesn't need to parse again).

may be retrieved from a cache store (e.g., Automated Persisted Queries).
At this stage, there is not a guarantee that the operation is not malformed.

function that's invoked with the resolver's result (or the error that it throws). The end hook is called when your resolver has

and its end hook are synchronous plugin APIs (i.e., they do not return

event fires when Apollo Server encounters errors while
parsing, validating, or executing a GraphQL operation.

event fires whenever Apollo Server is about to send a response
for a GraphQL operation. This event fires (and Apollo Server sends a response) even
if the GraphQL operation encounters one or more errors.
